title: Next.js + Laravel Might Be The Ultimate Combination

rawLines.text: Hey everyone, in this video we're going
to talk about Larafile and Next.js. So
I've been seeing some people wondering
whether you can actually combine them.
And actually the answer is yes. And it's
actually a really interesting
combination especially for people that
are already familiar with Laravel, but
you want to use some shiny new
technology next.js as your front end
perhaps and you want to use the Laravel
app as a back end. And by using this
setup, we can use Next.js for all sorts
of UI related manners like statically
generating our pages for example. And
then we can use Larafhal for all sorts
of backend functionalities. Right? So
maybe you are already familiar with
Larafhal or maybe you have a client
that's already familiar with Larafile
and you want to stick to Larafel for
your back end but you still want to try
out the shiny new technology next.js.
That's totally possible. In this video
I'll show you a way of doing that. So I
will actually show you an example of
using Larafel as a backend application
just exposing some API endpoints and
then our next app will be consuming
those API endpoints. We'll just build a
simple blog. So let's actually see how
we would go about doing that. All right.
So let's actually start with the
Larafhel app. I scaffolded a simple
Larafl app here mostly using AI. So
there's a bunch of things here we could
improve. But here I have uh a bunch of
API routes. Right? So here we will have
an API route for getting all the posts.
We're going to build a blog website and
the Lar app will just expose these API
endpoints so that our front end can get
the posts data by using either this one
to get all the posts or individual post
by using this. But maybe we also want to
add new posts or delete them. Right? So
just here in our blog controller, I'm
not using a database here. I just
hardcoded some posts. So it will just be
uh two posts. We have a first post title
first post content hello world. And then
we have a second post with some other
content. So when you hit the first one,
API post, you get all of them. Right? So
here this one we're just sending back
all the post in JSON format. And this
one will actually be well, let's
actually scroll down here. It's actually
this one. This will send you the
individual post. Okay, let's actually
quickly try this out and try to hit this
API endpoint. I will quickly run this
app. So, so I try going to that
localhost port 8000 and hit
API/post. We get our posts here. Let me
show this a little bit nicer. All right.
So, here we have our data. All right.
So, now I want to consume this from my
next application. I could set it up
locally here, but let's actually try

They are actually also a digital ocean

If I go back and we go to slash2, we see

right. So now we are consuming Larafal

right. Now, one of the benefits of using
NextJS is that we can statically
generate these pages. So, we can
generate the pages once during the build
and then when somebody uh goes here,
let's say to this posts one, we don't
have to generate this page on demand.
It's already finished. it's already
there waiting for the user. We can host
it on a CDN for example. And so that
would be optimal, right? So let's see
how we can quickly do that here in
next.js. If we want to see the pages

about which routes are static and

All right. So here it's going to say

and by default the pages are actually

uh run this page on demand. Meaning we

will have some output and the actual
markup that we can then serve over and
over again whenever there's somebody
coming to our website. That's optimal.
That's what we want if it's possible. So
by default the the routes are static.
However, sometimes that's not really
possible. For example, if you have a
dynamic route parameter like what we
have here with the ID. In that case,
next is basically saying, well, this ID
could be anything. To render this, it
needs an ID, but this ID could be
anything, right? It could be 1 million,
could be 500, could be two. This is
runtime information. So every time now
there's a request this page it has to
render that as the request is coming in
on the fly. This is not optimal. So
ideally we can also statically generate
this. So that's why we have this symbol

Now, I couldn't find that much

All right generating static pages. All
right. So now we can see that even for

right? So this is one way that you can

I want to thank you for watching. I want
